departmentDescription: The American Wing's ever-evolving collection comprises some 20,000 works by African American, Euro American, Native American, and Latin American artists, ranging from the colonial to early-modern period.
title: Great-Grand-Father's Tale of the Revolution—A Portrait of Reverend Zachariah Greene
description: This group portrait depicts the children of New York businessman Jacob Thuthill Vanderhoof and their maternal great-grandfather Reverend Zachariah Greene in the interior of the Vanderhoof residence. The family is surrounded by the trappings of a typical upper-middle-class parlor, including a tapestry velvet rug, elegant window draperies, a Rococo Revival armchair, and marble-topped center table—representing the aspirational lifestyle of mid-nineteenth-century American middle-class families.

departmentDescription: The American Wing's ever-evolving collection comprises some 20,000 works by African American, Euro American, Native American, and Latin American artists, ranging from the colonial to early-modern period.
title: River Scene
description: Bathed in the mellow sunshine of a late summer afternoon, this peaceful scene shows cattle ambling toward their unseen barn, casting long shadows across the rutted road. The low, gently sloped hills fade into the blue distance. Unlike typical Hudson River School landscapes with dramatic elements, this work's mood, tempo, and composition—emphasizing two splendid trees in diagonal division—relates more closely to English landscape painting traditions.

departmentDescription: The American Wing's ever-evolving collection comprises some 20,000 works by African American, Euro American, Native American, and Latin American artists, ranging from the colonial to early-modern period.
title: Ruth Gleaning

departmentDescription: The American Wing's ever-evolving collection comprises some 20,000 works by African American, Euro American, Native American, and Latin American artists, ranging from the colonial to early-modern period.
title: Washington Crossing the Delaware

departmentDescription: The American Wing's ever-evolving collection comprises some 20,000 works by African American, Euro American, Native American, and Latin American artists, ranging from the colonial to early-modern period.
title: Madame X (Virginie Amélie Avegno Gautreau)

departmentDescription: Includes more than 7,000 works ranging in date from the eighth millennium B.C. through the centuries just beyond the time of the Arab conquests of the seventh century A.D.
title: Furniture or cosmetic box plaque carved in relief with a striding bull
description: This curved ivory plaque features a striding bull in relief, bordered by stylized plant motifs. Found at Fort Shalmaneser in Nimrud, it originally formed part of a continuous frieze decorating furniture or a cosmetic box. The bull's heavy body fills the plaque space, characteristic of North Syrian ivory carving. Its deeply drilled eye would have held colored glass or semiprecious stone inlay, demonstrating the sophisticated decorative techniques of ancient Assyrian craftsmen.

departmentDescription: Includes more than 7,000 works ranging in date from the eighth millennium B.C. through the centuries just beyond the time of the Arab conquests of the seventh century A.D.
title: Antelope pendant
description: This elegant silver pendant depicts an antelope in a stylized form characteristic of Proto-Elamite art from ancient southwestern Iran. Dating to around 3100-2900 BCE, it represents some of humanity's earliest sophisticated metalworking techniques. The pendant likely held ceremonial or religious significance in ancient Mesopotamian culture, demonstrating the artistic achievement and cultural sophistication of early civilizations in the region that would later become the Persian Empire.

departmentDescription: Includes more than 7,000 works ranging in date from the eighth millennium B.C. through the centuries just beyond the time of the Arab conquests of the seventh century A.D.
title: Cuneiform cylinder: inscription of Nebuchadnezzar II describing the construction of the outer city wall of Babylon
description: This cuneiform cylinder bears an inscription by Nebuchadnezzar II, the famous Babylonian king who ruled from 604-562 BCE, describing the construction of Babylon's outer defensive wall. Such foundation cylinders were ceremonially buried in building foundations to commemorate major construction projects. The inscription demonstrates the administrative sophistication of the Neo-Babylonian Empire and Nebuchadnezzar's ambitious building programs, which included the legendary Hanging Gardens and the impressive city walls of Babylon.

departmentDescription: Includes more than 7,000 works ranging in date from the eighth millennium B.C. through the centuries just beyond the time of the Arab conquests of the seventh century A.D.
title: Human-headed winged bull (lamassu)

departmentDescription: Collecting, preserving, researching, publishing, and exhibiting distinguished examples representing the art of the armorer, swordsmith, and gunmaker.
title: Pair of Stirrups
description: This pair of 19th-century Chilean stirrups showcases the distinctive metalworking traditions of South American equestrian culture. Made from copper alloy, these stirrups reflect the importance of horsemanship in Chilean society and the skilled craftsmanship of local metalworkers. The substantial weight and robust construction indicate they were designed for practical use by riders traversing the varied terrain of the Chilean countryside, while their refined proportions suggest they belonged to a person of some social standing.

departmentDescription: Collecting, preserving, researching, publishing, and exhibiting distinguished examples representing the art of the armorer, swordsmith, and gunmaker.
title: Armor of Sir James Scudamore (1558–1619)
description: This magnificent suit of armor was crafted for Sir James Scudamore, a prominent Elizabethan courtier and Member of Parliament, by master armorer Jacob Halder at the Royal Workshops in Greenwich around 1595-96. The armor combines exceptional craftsmanship with practical protection, featuring intricate steel work enhanced with gold decoration. Scudamore was known for his participation in tournaments and his service to Queen Elizabeth I, making this armor both a status symbol and functional military equipment of the English Renaissance court.

departmentDescription: Collecting, preserving, researching, publishing, and exhibiting distinguished examples representing the art of the armorer, swordsmith, and gunmaker.
title: Armor of Henry II, King of France (reigned 1547–59)

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Plaque: Warrior and Attendants
description: This brass plaque from the Kingdom of Benin (in present-day Nigeria) depicts a warrior chief flanked by attendants carrying shields and spears. Created during the 16th-17th centuries, it once decorated the columns of the royal palace in Benin City. The sophisticated lost-wax casting technique and detailed imagery celebrate the military prowess and courtly hierarchy of the powerful Edo empire. Such plaques served both decorative and commemorative purposes, recording important historical events and honoring royal achievements.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Lupona (royal seat)
artistDisplayName: Buli Master, possibly Ngongo ya Chintu (Hemba, ca. 1810-1870)
description: This exquisite royal stool (lupona) was created by the renowned Buli Master, possibly Ngongo ya Chintu, for the Hemba people of central Africa. The stool features a carved female caryatid figure supporting the seat, demonstrating the sophisticated woodcarving traditions of the region. Such royal seats were symbols of political authority and spiritual power, used in important ceremonies and meetings. The elegant proportions and skilled craftsmanship reflect the high artistic standards of 19th-century African court art.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Seated Chief (Mwanangana) Playing Sanza
medium: Wood (uapaca), cloth, fiber, beads, dyes, resinous coating
description: This carved wooden figure depicts a Chokwe chief (mwanangana) playing a sanza, a traditional African thumb piano. Created in the 19th century by Chokwe artists from central Africa, the sculpture combines wood, cloth, fiber, beads, and dyes to create a lifelike representation. The figure celebrates the cultural importance of music in African society and the role of chiefs as cultural leaders. The detailed craftsmanship and mixed materials demonstrate the sophisticated artistic techniques of the Chokwe people.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Relief with enthroned ruler
description: This limestone relief by the Maya artist Chakalte' depicts an enthroned ruler in elaborate costume and regalia, dating to 770 CE during the Late Classic period. The sophisticated carving shows the ruler seated on a throne, surrounded by hieroglyphic inscriptions that record important historical information. Such reliefs were integral to Maya royal propaganda, commemorating rulers and their achievements while legitimizing their divine authority. The work demonstrates the high artistic skill and complex political culture of ancient Maya civilization.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Smiling figure (Sonriente)
description: This ceramic figure from the Classic Veracruz period represents the distinctive 'Sonriente' (smiling figure) tradition of south central Veracruz, Mexico. Created between 600-1000 CE, the sculpture depicts a joyful male figure with an animated expression and dynamic pose. These smiling figures are unique to Veracruz art and likely had ritual significance, possibly related to ceremonies celebrating life, fertility, or seasonal cycles. The figure's exuberant demeanor and masterful ceramic craftsmanship reflect the sophisticated artistic traditions of pre-Columbian Mexico.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Funerary mask
description: This spectacular funerary mask was created by Lambayeque (Sicán) artisans from Peru's north coast during 900-1100 CE. Made of gold with silver-copper alloy details and cinnabar pigment, the mask exemplifies the extraordinary metalworking skills of pre-Columbian Andean civilizations. Such masks were placed over the faces of elite individuals during burial, symbolizing their transformation into divine beings in the afterlife. The elaborate craftsmanship and precious materials reflect the deceased's high social status and the Sicán culture's sophisticated understanding of metallurgy.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Priest with raised arms

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Pendant mask of Ìyọ́bà Idià
artistDisplayName: Ìgbèsànmwà (ivory- and wood- carving guild) artists
medium: Ivory, iron, brass, coal, traces of iron oxides

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Body mask
medium: Mulberry fiber, rattan, sago palm leaves, wood, bamboo, cassowary bone, cassowary feathers, feathers, coix seeds, pigment

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of art of the peoples of sub-Saharan Africa, the Pacific Islands, and North, Central, and South America comprises more than eleven thousand works of art of varied materials and types, representing diverse cultural traditions from as early as 3000 B.C.E. to the present.
title: Banda mask

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Asian art—more than 35,000 objects, ranging in date from the third millennium B.C. to the twenty-first century—is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world.
title: Buddha of Medicine Bhaishajyaguru (Yaoshi fo)
medium: Water-based pigment over foundation of clay mixed with straw
description: This monumental wall painting depicts Bhaishajyaguru, the Buddha of Medicine, surrounded by attendant bodhisattvas and celestial beings. Created around 1319 during the Yuan dynasty, this massive work originally adorned a Buddhist temple in Shanxi Province. The Buddha of Medicine was revered for his power to heal physical and spiritual ailments. The painting's extraordinary scale and rich pigmentation demonstrate the importance of Buddhist art in medieval China and the sophisticated techniques used to create devotional imagery that inspired faith and contemplation.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Asian art—more than 35,000 objects, ranging in date from the third millennium B.C. to the twenty-first century—is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world.
title: Discussion of Buddhist Principles by Tettō Gikō
dimensions:
Image: 22 5/8 × 14 9/16 in. (57.4 × 37 cm)
Overall with mounting: 58 1/2 × 19 7/16 in. (148.6 × 49.4 cm)
Overall with knobs: 58 1/2 × 21 11/16 in. (148.6 × 55.1 cm)
description: This hanging scroll features calligraphy by the renowned Zen monk Ikkyū Sōjun, one of Japan's most celebrated religious figures and poets. Created in the late 15th century, the work contains a discussion of Buddhist principles originally written by Tettō Gikō. Ikkyū's distinctive calligraphic style reflects his unconventional approach to Zen Buddhism and his reputation as both a profound spiritual teacher and cultural innovator. The flowing brushwork embodies the Zen aesthetic of spontaneity and direct expression of enlightened consciousness.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Asian art—more than 35,000 objects, ranging in date from the third millennium B.C. to the twenty-first century—is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world.
title: Album of Marvelous Landscapes (Kikanchō)
medium: Accordion album; ink and color on paper
description: This accordion-format album showcases the landscape painting skills of Tanomura Chokunyū, a master of the Nanga (Southern School) painting tradition in 19th-century Japan. The album contains multiple views of 'marvelous landscapes' rendered in ink and color, demonstrating the artist's ability to capture both intimate scenes and dramatic vistas. Chokunyū's work reflects the Japanese adaptation of Chinese literati painting styles, emphasizing poetic expression and scholarly refinement while incorporating distinctly Japanese sensibilities toward nature and composition.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Asian art—more than 35,000 objects, ranging in date from the third millennium B.C. to the twenty-first century—is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world.
title: Bust of Hevajra

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Asian art—more than 35,000 objects, ranging in date from the third millennium B.C. to the twenty-first century—is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world.
title: Kurukulla
medium: Appliqued satin, brocade and damask, embroidered silk and painted details

departmentDescription: Displayed in both The Met Fifth Avenue and in the Museum's branch in northern Manhattan, The Met Cloisters, the collection encompasses the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome in the fourth century to the beginning of the Renaissance in the early sixteenth century.
title: Adoration of the Magi from Seven Scenes from the Life of Christ
medium: Pot-metal and colorless glass, vitreous paint and silver stain
description: This stained glass panel depicts the Adoration of the Magi, one of seven scenes from the Life of Christ created around 1390 in Austria. The work demonstrates the sophisticated glassmaking techniques of the late medieval period, using pot-metal glass, vitreous paint, and silver stain to create rich colors and fine details. The composition shows the three wise men presenting gifts to the infant Jesus, with the Virgin Mary and Joseph present. Such panels originally adorned church windows, where the colored light would have created a mystical atmosphere conducive to prayer and contemplation.

departmentDescription: Displayed in both The Met Fifth Avenue and in the Museum's branch in northern Manhattan, The Met Cloisters, the collection encompasses the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome in the fourth century to the beginning of the Renaissance in the early sixteenth century.
title: Portal from the Church of San Leonardo al Frigido
description: This remarkable Romanesque portal was carved around 1175 by the master sculptor Biduinus for the Church of San Leonardo al Frigido in Tuscany. The architectural sculpture features elaborate Biblical scenes including the Annunciation, Visitation, and figures of apostles, carved in high relief with exceptional skill. Lions and other symbolic animals support the columns, while intricate foliate decoration fills the available space. Biduinus was one of the most accomplished sculptors of the 12th century, and this portal demonstrates the revival of monumental stone carving during the Romanesque period.

departmentDescription: Displayed in both The Met Fifth Avenue and in the Museum's branch in northern Manhattan, The Met Cloisters, the collection encompasses the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome in the fourth century to the beginning of the Renaissance in the early sixteenth century.
title: Chapter House from Notre-Dame-de-Pontaut
description: This complete 12th-century chapter house was relocated from the abbey of Notre-Dame-de-Pontaut in Gascony, France. The chapter house served as the meeting room where monks gathered daily to hear readings from their rule and conduct monastery business. The limestone architecture features the rounded arches, thick walls, and sturdy construction characteristic of Romanesque style. The carved capitals display intricate foliate and figural decoration typical of 12th-century monastic art. Such spaces embodied the spiritual and communal life of medieval monasteries, where architecture served both practical and symbolic functions.

departmentDescription: Displayed in both The Met Fifth Avenue and in the Museum's branch in northern Manhattan, The Met Cloisters, the collection encompasses the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome in the fourth century to the beginning of the Renaissance in the early sixteenth century.
title: Saint-Guilhem Cloister

departmentDescription: The Costume Institute's collection of more than 33,000 costumes and accessories represents five continents and seven centuries of fashionable dress and accessories for men, women, and children.
title: Evening dress
description: This elegant evening dress created by Wechsler & Abraham around 1880 exemplifies the sophisticated fashion of the Gilded Age in America. Made of luxurious silk, the gown reflects the elaborate aesthetic preferences of wealthy American society during this period of rapid industrialization and cultural refinement. The dress's construction and styling demonstrate the high level of craftsmanship achieved by American fashion houses as they competed with European couturiers to dress the nation's social elite for formal occasions.

departmentDescription: The Costume Institute's collection of more than 33,000 costumes and accessories represents five continents and seven centuries of fashionable dress and accessories for men, women, and children.
title: "On Liberty"

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of drawings and prints—one of the most comprehensive and distinguished of its kind in the world—began with a gift of 670 works from Cornelius Vanderbilt, a Museum trustee, in 1880.
title: Allegory of the Arts
medium: Pen and black ink, brush and brown wash, over faint black chalk underdrawing
description: This neoclassical drawing by Joseph Marie Vien depicts an allegorical scene celebrating the fine arts. Created in 1796, the work demonstrates Vien's mastery of drawing techniques, combining pen and ink with brown wash over chalk underdrawing. As a leading figure in the French Academy and teacher of Jacques-Louis David, Vien played a crucial role in the development of neoclassical art. The allegory reflects 18th-century ideals about the nobility and civilizing influence of artistic pursuits in society.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of drawings and prints—one of the most comprehensive and distinguished of its kind in the world—began with a gift of 670 works from Cornelius Vanderbilt, a Museum trustee, in 1880.
title: Sperm whale beached near Berkhey on 3 February, 1598
description: This engraving by Jacob Matham documents a specific historical event—the beaching of a sperm whale near Berkhey (now Katwijk) on February 3, 1598. Such whale strandings were rare and significant events in the Netherlands, often drawing large crowds and being interpreted as omens. Matham's detailed print serves both as documentary record and artistic interpretation, showing the massive whale surrounded by curious onlookers on horseback and on foot, reflecting Dutch society's fascination with natural phenomena and maritime encounters.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of drawings and prints—one of the most comprehensive and distinguished of its kind in the world—began with a gift of 670 works from Cornelius Vanderbilt, a Museum trustee, in 1880.
title: Bonaparte reviving the city of Lyon
medium: Pen and brown ink, brush and brown wash, over black chalk, heightened with white gouache
description: This allegorical drawing by Pierre Henri Revoil depicts Napoleon Bonaparte as the restorer of Lyon after the city's destruction during the French Revolution. Created around 1800-1804, during the height of Napoleon's popularity, the work uses classical imagery to glorify Bonaparte's role in rebuilding and revitalizing French cities. Revoil's sophisticated technique, combining ink, wash, and gouache, creates a dramatic composition that celebrates Napoleon's domestic achievements alongside his military conquests, reflecting the propaganda needs of the Consulate period.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of ancient Egyptian art consists of approximately 26,000 objects of artistic, historical, and cultural importance, dating from the Paleolithic to the Roman period.
title: Shabti of Yuya
dimensions: H. 28.5 cm (11 1/4 in.); w. at elbows 7.8 cm (3 1/16 in.); d. at foot 5.4 cm (2 1/8 in.)
description: This beautifully preserved shabti figure belonged to Yuya, father-in-law of Pharaoh Amenhotep III and grandfather of Queen Tiye. Made of cedar wood with painted details and Egyptian blue pigment, it dates to around 1390-1352 BCE. Shabtis were magical servant figures placed in tombs to perform agricultural labor for the deceased in the afterlife. This example's exceptional craftsmanship reflects Yuya's high status at court. The figure's crossed arms and mummiform appearance follow traditional conventions while the fine materials demonstrate the wealth and importance of this royal family member.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of ancient Egyptian art consists of approximately 26,000 objects of artistic, historical, and cultural importance, dating from the Paleolithic to the Roman period.
title: Sphinx of Hatshepsut

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of ancient Egyptian art consists of approximately 26,000 objects of artistic, historical, and cultural importance, dating from the Paleolithic to the Roman period.
title: Head of a King, Possibly Seankhkare Mentuhotep III
description: This limestone royal head, dating to around 2000-1988 BCE, possibly represents King Seankhkare Mentuhotep III of the Middle Kingdom's 11th Dynasty. The sculpture demonstrates the distinctive artistic style of the period following Egypt's reunification after the First Intermediate Period. The king wears the traditional nemes headdress, and the subtle modeling of facial features reflects the renewed confidence and artistic sophistication of Middle Kingdom royal portraiture. The work exemplifies the period's balance between idealized divine kingship and more naturalistic human characteristics.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of ancient Egyptian art consists of approximately 26,000 objects of artistic, historical, and cultural importance, dating from the Paleolithic to the Roman period.
title: Stela of Dedu
description: This painted limestone stela from the Middle Kingdom commemorates Dedu and his wife Sitsobek, demonstrating the democratization of funerary monuments during this period. The relief shows the couple seated before an offering table laden with bread, beer, and other provisions for the afterlife. Hieroglyphic inscriptions identify the figures and invoke blessings for their eternal sustenance. Such stelae reflect the Middle Kingdom's artistic refinement and the growing accessibility of elaborate burial customs to non-royal Egyptians.

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Self-Portrait with a Straw Hat (obverse: The Potato Peeler)
description: Van Gogh produced more than twenty self-portraits during his Parisian sojourn (1886–88). Short of funds but determined to hone his skills as a figure painter, he became his own best sitter. This picture shows the artist's awareness of Neo-Impressionist technique and color theory, with vibrant brushstrokes creating a dynamic surface. Painted on the reverse of an earlier peasant study, it demonstrates Van Gogh's economical use of materials while showcasing his evolving artistic style during his transformative Paris period.

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Self-Portrait
description: Rembrandt was a dedicated self-portraitist all his life, and roughly forty self-portraits by him survive today. In this example, painted when Rembrandt was fifty-four, the artist was unsparing in depicting the signs of aging in his own face, building up the paint in high relief to convey his furrowed brow, heavy pouches beneath his eyes, and double chin. The work demonstrates Rembrandt's mastery of oil painting and his unflinching psychological honesty in confronting mortality and the passage of time.

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Study for "A Sunday on La Grande Jatte"
description: This preparatory study for Seurat's masterpiece 'A Sunday on La Grande Jatte' demonstrates the artist's revolutionary pointillist technique and scientific approach to color. Created in 1884, the work shows figures enjoying leisure time along the Seine, rendered in small dots of pure color that optically blend when viewed from a distance. Seurat's methodical application of color theory and his systematic study of light and atmosphere marked a radical departure from Impressionism, founding the Neo-Impressionist movement.

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Garden at Sainte-Adresse

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: The Death of Socrates

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Young Woman with a Water Pitcher

departmentDescription: The Met's celebrated European Paintings collection encompasses more than 2,500 works of art from the thirteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Bridge over a Pond of Water Lilies

departmentDescription: The Met's comprehensive collection of European sculpture and decorative arts reflect the development of a number of art forms in Western European countries from the early fifteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Temperance
dimensions: Overall, height to upper surface of integral plinth (confirmed): H. 69 5/8 x W. 25 3/8 x D. 30 7/8 in. (176.8 x 64.5 x 78.4 cm)
description: This marble sculpture by Giovanni Caccini represents Temperance, one of the four cardinal virtues in Christian theology. Created in 1583-84 during the height of the Italian Renaissance, the work demonstrates Caccini's mastery of classical form and allegorical representation. The female figure embodies the virtue of moderation and self-restraint, carved with elegant drapery and graceful proportions that reflect Renaissance ideals of beauty and moral instruction. The sculpture exemplifies the period's integration of classical mythology, Christian values, and humanist philosophy.

departmentDescription: The Met's comprehensive collection of European sculpture and decorative arts reflect the development of a number of art forms in Western European countries from the early fifteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Ugolino and His Sons
dimensions:
Overall (confirmed): 77 3/4 × 59 × 43 1/2 in., 4955 lb. (197.5 × 149.9 × 110.5 cm, 2247.6 kg);
Pedestal (wt. confirmed): 3759 lb. (1705.1 kg)
description: This dramatic marble sculpture by Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux depicts the tragic story of Count Ugolino from Dante's Inferno, showing the nobleman imprisoned with his sons and grandsons, condemned to starve. Created between 1865-67, the work exemplifies 19th-century Romantic sculpture with its emotional intensity and dynamic composition. Carpeaux's masterful carving captures the anguish of the figures while demonstrating exceptional technical skill in rendering flesh, expressions, and the complex interweaving of bodies. The sculpture reflects the period's fascination with literary themes and psychological drama.

departmentDescription: The Met's comprehensive collection of European sculpture and decorative arts reflect the development of a number of art forms in Western European countries from the early fifteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Marsyas
medium: Marble on a black marble socle inlaid with light marble panels
dimensions:
confirmed: 27 × 17 3/8 × 11 1/8 in., 133.8 lb. (68.6 × 44.1 × 28.3 cm, 60.7 kg)
socle, confirmed: 6 1/4 in. (15.9 cm)
yellow marble display column (wt confirmed): 644 lb. (295.7 kg)
description: This powerful marble bust by Balthasar Permoser depicts Marsyas, the satyr from Greek mythology who challenged Apollo to a musical contest and was flayed alive as punishment. Created around 1680-85, the sculpture captures the moment of Marsyas's agony with extraordinary emotional intensity and technical virtuosity. Permoser's dramatic interpretation reflects the Baroque aesthetic's emphasis on psychological drama and physical suffering. The work demonstrates the artist's mastery of marble carving and his ability to convey both classical mythological themes and raw human emotion.

departmentDescription: The Met's comprehensive collection of European sculpture and decorative arts reflect the development of a number of art forms in Western European countries from the early fifteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Boiserie from the Hôtel de Varengeville
description: This exquisite boiserie (wood paneling) originally adorned the salon of the Hôtel de Varengeville in Paris, representing the pinnacle of French Rococo interior design. Created around 1736-52, the carved, painted, and gilded oak panels showcase the asymmetrical ornamentation, pastel colors, and naturalistic motifs characteristic of the Rococo style. The sophisticated craftsmanship and elegant proportions reflect the refined taste of French aristocracy during the reign of Louis XV. Such interiors created intimate, luxurious environments for social gatherings and private conversations.

departmentDescription: The Met's comprehensive collection of European sculpture and decorative arts reflect the development of a number of art forms in Western European countries from the early fifteenth through the early twentieth century.
title: Paris
objectDate: ca. 1822–23, original marble version completed November 1812

title: Herakles the Archer

title: Lucretia

title: Bacchanal: A Faun Teased by Children

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of Greek and Roman art comprises more than 30,000 works ranging in date from the Neolithic period to the time of the Roman emperor Constantine's conversion to Christianity in A.D. 312.
objectType: Statue of a boy, Gaius Caesar ?
title: Bronze statue of an aristocratic boy
description: This life-sized bronze statue was found on the island of Rhodes and depicts an aristocratic Roman boy from the Augustan period (27 BCE–14 CE). With his broad face and short hair, the boy resembles young princes in the family of Augustus, the first Roman emperor. He wears a Greek himation (cloak) instead of the traditional Roman toga, reflecting the cultural interchange between Roman and Greek traditions. The sculpture demonstrates the exceptional bronze-casting skills of ancient artists and the cosmopolitan nature of Roman society in the eastern Mediterranean.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of Greek and Roman art comprises more than 30,000 works ranging in date from the Neolithic period to the time of the Roman emperor Constantine's conversion to Christianity in A.D. 312.
objectType: Akroterion of a gravestone with palmette
title: Marble akroterion
dimensions:
H. through center  4 1/8 in. (10.5 cm)
greatest width as restored  28 3/4 in. (73 cm)
description: This marble akroterion (decorative crowning element) once topped an Attic gravestone from the 4th century BCE. The elegant palmette design exemplifies the refined decorative vocabulary of Classical Greek art. Such architectural ornaments were placed at the apex of funerary monuments to provide a dignified crowning element that drew the eye upward. The sophisticated carving and balanced proportions reflect the Greek aesthetic principles of harmony and proportion that influenced Western art for millennia. The palmette motif, derived from the palm leaf, symbolized victory and eternal life.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of Greek and Roman art comprises more than 30,000 works ranging in date from the Neolithic period to the time of the Roman emperor Constantine's conversion to Christianity in A.D. 312.
title: Marble column from the Temple of Artemis at Sardis
description: This impressive marble column with its Ionic capital originally stood in the Temple of Artemis at Sardis, the ancient capital of Lydia in modern-day Turkey. Dating to around 300 BCE, the column represents the refined architectural achievements of the Hellenistic period. The elegant Ionic capital, with its characteristic volutes (spiral scrolls), demonstrates the sophisticated engineering and aesthetic sensibilities of ancient Greek architects. The temple was one of the largest in the ancient world, rivaling the famous Temple of Artemis at Ephesus, one of the Seven Wonders.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of Greek and Roman art comprises more than 30,000 works ranging in date from the Neolithic period to the time of the Roman emperor Constantine's conversion to Christianity in A.D. 312.
title: Marble statue of a youthful Hercules

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Islamic art is one of the most comprehensive in the world and ranges in date from the seventh to the twenty-first century. Its more than 15,000 objects reflect the great diversity and range of the cultural traditions from Spain to Indonesia.
title: Incense Burner of Amir Saif al-Dunya wa'l-Din ibn Muhammad al-Mawardi
dimensions:
OveralL. H. 33 1/2 in. (85.1 cm)
               L. 32 1/2 in. (82.6 cm)
               W. 9 in. (22.9 cm)
L. from heel of back foot to toe of front foot: 22 in. (55.9 cm)
L. from toe of front foot to tip of nose: 4 in. (10.2 cm)
L. from heel of back foot to tip of taiL. 7 in. (17.8 cm)
description: This magnificent bronze incense burner in the shape of a feline was created by the master metalworker Ja'far ibn Muhammad ibn 'Ali in 1181-82 CE for Amir Saif al-Dunya wa'l-Din ibn Muhammad al-Mawardi. The hollow bronze body served as a container for burning incense, with smoke emerging through decorative perforations. The surface is elaborately decorated with engraved and chased designs featuring calligraphy, geometric patterns, and arabesques. Such luxury objects demonstrate the sophisticated metalworking techniques and artistic patronage of the Islamic world during the Ayyubid period.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Islamic art is one of the most comprehensive in the world and ranges in date from the seventh to the twenty-first century. Its more than 15,000 objects reflect the great diversity and range of the cultural traditions from Spain to Indonesia.
title: Damascus Room
medium: Wood (poplar) with gesso relief, gold and tin leaf, glazes and paint; wood (cypress, poplar, and mulberry), mother-of-pearl, marble and other stones, stucco with glass, plaster ceramic tiles, iron, brass
dimensions:
Overall:
           H. 264 7/16 in. (671.6 cm)
           W. 200 1/2 in. (509.2 cm)
           D. 316 5/8 in. (804.2 cm)
From inside front entrance to back wall:
           H. 316 5/8 in. (804.2 cm)
Fountain:
           H. 4 15/16 in. (12.5 cm)
description: This complete interior from an Ottoman-period house in Damascus, dated 1707 CE, represents the pinnacle of Syrian decorative arts. The room features intricately carved and painted wooden panels (called 'ajami) decorated with geometric patterns, floral motifs, and Arabic calligraphy in gold and bright colors. Mother-of-pearl inlays add luminous accents throughout. The central marble fountain and raised seating areas (diwan) reflect traditional Middle Eastern domestic architecture. Such rooms served as reception halls for male guests, demonstrating the wealth and artistic sophistication of their owners.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Islamic art is one of the most comprehensive in the world and ranges in date from the seventh to the twenty-first century. Its more than 15,000 objects reflect the great diversity and range of the cultural traditions from Spain to Indonesia.
title: The Lovers
medium: Opaque watercolor, ink, and gold on paper
description: This exquisite painting by Riza-yi 'Abbasi, dated 1630 CE, depicts an intimate scene of lovers in the refined style of Safavid Persian art. The master painter was renowned for his delicate brushwork and sophisticated use of color. The composition shows a couple in elegant dress, rendered with the flowing lines and subtle modeling characteristic of 17th-century Isfahan painting. Riza's work represents the height of Persian miniature painting, combining traditional Persian artistic conventions with new naturalistic influences, creating works of exceptional beauty and emotional subtlety.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Islamic art is one of the most comprehensive in the world and ranges in date from the seventh to the twenty-first century. Its more than 15,000 objects reflect the great diversity and range of the cultural traditions from Spain to Indonesia.
title: Mihrab (Prayer Niche)
medium: Mosaic of polychrome-glazed cut tiles on stonepaste body; set into mortar
description: This magnificent mihrab (prayer niche) was created in 1354-55 CE using intricate mosaic tilework typical of Iranian ceramic artistry. The architectural element would have indicated the direction of Mecca (qibla) in a mosque or madrasa. The surface is covered with lustrous polychrome-glazed tiles arranged in geometric and calligraphic patterns, featuring verses from the Quran rendered in elegant Arabic script. The sophisticated tilework demonstrates the technical mastery and artistic sophistication of 14th-century Islamic ceramics, combining religious function with extraordinary decorative beauty.

departmentDescription: The Met's collection of Islamic art is one of the most comprehensive in the world and ranges in date from the seventh to the twenty-first century. Its more than 15,000 objects reflect the great diversity and range of the cultural traditions from Spain to Indonesia.
title: Pierced Window Screen (Jali)
dimensions:

departmentDescription: The Robert Lehman Collection is one of the most distinguished privately assembled art collections in the United States. Robert Lehman's bequest to The Met is a remarkable example of twentieth-century American collecting.
title: The Assumption of the Virgin
description: This tempera painting by Bernardo Daddi depicts the Assumption of the Virgin Mary, showing her ascension to heaven surrounded by angels. Created around 1337-39, the work exemplifies the refined style of 14th-century Florentine painting. Daddi was a follower of Giotto and helped develop the more graceful, decorative style that would influence later Renaissance art. The composition features the Virgin in a mandorla (almond-shaped aureole) supported by angels, painted against a luminous gold ground that creates a sense of divine radiance and spiritual transcendence.

departmentDescription: The Robert Lehman Collection is one of the most distinguished privately assembled art collections in the United States. Robert Lehman's bequest to The Met is a remarkable example of twentieth-century American collecting.
title: The Last Supper
dimensions: Overall, with engaged (modern) frame, 15 x 22 1/4 in. (38.1 x 56.5 cm); painted surface 13 1/2 x 20 3/4 in. (34.3 x 52.7 cm)
description: This tempera painting by Ugolino da Siena depicts the Last Supper, showing Christ and the twelve apostles at the moment Jesus announces his betrayal. Created around 1325-30, the work represents the refined style of early 14th-century Sienese painting. Ugolino was influenced by Duccio and helped establish Siena as a major center of artistic innovation. The composition arranges the figures around a table with Christ at center, painted against a gold ground that creates a sense of sacred space and divine presence typical of medieval religious art.

departmentDescription: The Robert Lehman Collection is one of the most distinguished privately assembled art collections in the United States. Robert Lehman's bequest to The Met is a remarkable example of twentieth-century American collecting.
title: Aquamanile in the Form of Aristotle and Phyllis
medium:
Bronze; Quaternary copper alloy (approx. 72% copper, approx. 17% zinc,
approx. 6% lead, approx. 3% tin).
description: This remarkable bronze aquamanile (water vessel) depicts the legendary story of Aristotle and Phyllis, a popular medieval tale about the philosopher being ridden like a horse by his student Alexander's lover. Created in the late 14th or early 15th century in the southern Netherlands, the vessel combines practical function with moralizing narrative. Such objects served for ritual hand-washing during religious ceremonies or formal meals. The story illustrated here was intended to show how even the wisest men could be overcome by feminine wiles, reflecting medieval attitudes toward both classical learning and gender.

departmentDescription: With its collection of more than one million volumes, extensive digital collections, and online resources, Watson Library is one of the world's most comprehensive art libraries.
title: Les proportions du corps humain, mesurées sur les plus belles figures de l'antiquité
description: This 1683 treatise by Girard Audran examines human proportions as measured from the most beautiful figures of antiquity. Audran was a French engraver and theorist who sought to codify the ideal proportions found in classical sculpture and apply them to artistic training. The work contains 30 plates illustrating anatomical measurements and proportional relationships, reflecting the 17th-century academic approach to art education. Such treatises were essential tools for artists learning to draw the human figure according to classical standards of beauty and proportion established by ancient Greek and Roman masters.

departmentDescription: With its collection of more than one million volumes, extensive digital collections, and online resources, Watson Library is one of the world's most comprehensive art libraries.
title: Dialogos de la pintvra : sv defensa, origen, essecia, definicion, modos y diferencias
description: This 1633 treatise by Vicente Carducho represents one of the most important theoretical works on painting from the Spanish Golden Age. Written as a series of dialogues, the book defends painting as a liberal art rather than mere craft, discussing its origins, essence, definition, methods, and varieties. Carducho, a prominent painter at the Spanish court, sought to elevate the status of artists and establish painting's intellectual foundations. The work reflects the broader European movement to theorize art during the Baroque period, combining practical instruction with philosophical discourse about the nature and purpose of artistic creation.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of medieval and Byzantine art is among the most comprehensive in the world, encompassing the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome to the beginning of the Renaissance.
title: Crossbow Brooch
description: This exceptional gold brooch from around 430 CE exemplifies the luxury metalwork of the late Roman or early Byzantine period. The crossbow fibula design was popular among high-ranking military officers and wealthy civilians during the 4th-5th centuries. The sophisticated goldsmithing techniques and substantial weight indicate it belonged to someone of considerable status, possibly a government official or military commander. Such brooches served both practical and symbolic functions, fastening garments while displaying the wearer's rank and wealth. The piece reflects the artistic continuity between the late Roman Empire and emerging Byzantine culture.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of medieval and Byzantine art is among the most comprehensive in the world, encompassing the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome to the beginning of the Renaissance.
title: Tip of a Pointer
description: This tiny but exquisite cloisonné enamel object served as the tip of a pointer used during religious ceremonies to follow text during readings. Created between 1080-1150 during the height of the Byzantine Empire, it demonstrates the exceptional skill of Byzantine enamelers. The cloisonné technique involves creating cells (cloisons) with thin gold wires, then filling them with colored glass enamel and firing. Despite its minute size, the piece showcases the sophisticated decorative arts that flourished in Constantinople. Such liturgical objects combined practical function with spiritual beauty, reflecting Byzantine values about the role of art in religious worship.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of medieval and Byzantine art is among the most comprehensive in the world, encompassing the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome to the beginning of the Renaissance.
title: Game Piece with a Scene from the Life of Apollonius of Tyre
description: This miniature walrus ivory game piece from around 1170 depicts a scene from the medieval romance of Apollonius of Tyre, a popular story throughout medieval Europe. The tiny carving shows remarkable detail despite its diminutive size, illustrating figures in a boat - likely representing Apollonius's sea voyages. Created in Germany during the Romanesque period, such game pieces demonstrate both the skill of medieval ivory carvers and the widespread popularity of literary narratives. The story of Apollonius, a tale of adventure, love, and redemption, was known across Europe and influenced later works including Shakespeare's Pericles.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of medieval and Byzantine art is among the most comprehensive in the world, encompassing the art of the Mediterranean and Europe from the fall of Rome to the beginning of the Renaissance.
title: Virgin and Child

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of musical instruments includes approximately 5,000 examples from six continents and the Pacific Islands, dating from about 300 B.C. to the present.
title: ex "Kurtz" Violin
dimensions:
Height: 22 5/8 in. (57.4 cm)
Width: 7 15/16 in. (20.2 cm)
description: This violin by Andrea Amati represents one of the earliest examples of the modern violin, created around 1560 in Cremona, Italy. Amati is credited with establishing the basic proportions and construction methods that define the violin family. The instrument features the characteristic Amati craftsmanship: elegant proportions, beautiful varnish, and exceptional tonal qualities. Made from spruce and maple with ebony fittings and decorative gilding, it demonstrates the sophisticated woodworking skills that made Cremona the center of violin making. The Amati workshop founded a dynasty of violin makers that influenced instrument construction for centuries.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of musical instruments includes approximately 5,000 examples from six continents and the Pacific Islands, dating from about 300 B.C. to the present.
title: Pipe Organ
medium: Mahogany veneer, rosewood veneer, pine, gilt, ivory, ebony, maple, walnut, chestnut, metal
description: This 1830 pipe organ by Thomas Appleton represents American organ building during the early 19th century. Appleton was one of Boston's leading organ builders, known for instruments that combined European traditions with American innovations. The organ features mahogany and rosewood veneers with decorative gilt details, reflecting the refined taste of the period. The instrument demonstrates the growing sophistication of American musical instrument making and the important role of church music in early American culture. Such organs were central to both religious worship and secular musical life in 19th-century America.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of musical instruments includes approximately 5,000 examples from six continents and the Pacific Islands, dating from about 300 B.C. to the present.
title: Grand Piano
dimensions:
Height (Total): 34 1/16 (86.5 cm)
Width (Parallel to keyboard): 37 5/8 (95.6 cm)
Depth (Case length, perpendicular to keyboard): 90 in. (228.6 cm)
description: This 1720 grand piano by Bartolomeo Cristofori is one of only three surviving instruments by the inventor of the piano. Cristofori, working in Florence for the Medici court, developed the mechanism that allowed players to control volume through touch—hence the original name 'gravicembalo col piano e forte' (harpsichord with soft and loud). This revolutionary instrument replaced the plucked strings of the harpsichord with hammers that struck the strings, creating dynamic expression previously impossible. The elegant cypress case reflects Italian craftsmanship, while the innovative action mechanism launched a musical revolution that transformed keyboard music forever.

departmentDescription: The Museum's collection of musical instruments includes approximately 5,000 examples from six continents and the Pacific Islands, dating from about 300 B.C. to the present.
title: Breasted Drum
dimensions:

departmentDescription: The Met's Department of Photographs houses a collection of more than 75,000 works spanning the history of photography from its invention in the 1830s to the present.
title: [Disabled Union Soldiers Posed in Aid of the U.S. Sanitary Commission at the New York Metropolitan Fair]
medium: Albumen silver print from glass negative
dimensions:
Image: 3 1/2 × 2 3/16 in. (8.9 × 5.6 cm)
Sheet: 3 1/2 × 2 3/16 in. (8.9 × 5.6 cm)
Mount: 4 in. × 2 1/2 in. (10.2 × 6.3 cm)
Group frame: either 14 x 11 in. or 17 x 14 in.
description: This powerful carte-de-visite photograph by J. Gurney & Son from April 1864 shows disabled Union soldiers who posed to support the U.S. Sanitary Commission at the New York Metropolitan Fair. The image serves as both documentary evidence of the Civil War's human cost and a fundraising tool for medical relief efforts. The Sanitary Commission was a civilian organization that provided medical supplies and care to Union forces. Such photographs brought the reality of war to the home front, humanizing the conflict while supporting humanitarian causes. The formal studio setting contrasts poignantly with the subjects' visible injuries.

departmentDescription: The Met's Department of Photographs houses a collection of more than 75,000 works spanning the history of photography from its invention in the 1830s to the present.
title: Paul Poujaud, Mme. Arthur Fontaine, and Degas
description: This 1895 photograph by Edgar Degas shows the artist's friend Paul Poujaud, Mme. Arthur Fontaine, and Degas himself in an intimate interior setting. Degas was an accomplished photographer who used the medium to explore composition and lighting effects that informed his paintings. The carefully arranged group portrait demonstrates his sophisticated understanding of photographic techniques and his interest in capturing informal, candid moments. The photograph reveals Degas's social circle and provides insight into late 19th-century Parisian artistic life, while showcasing the artist's experimental approach to this relatively new medium.

departmentDescription: The Met's Department of Photographs houses a collection of more than 75,000 works spanning the history of photography from its invention in the 1830s to the present.
title: Frederick Douglass
description: This circa 1855 daguerreotype portrait captures Frederick Douglass, the renowned abolitionist, orator, and social reformer. Douglass was one of the most photographed Americans of the 19th century and understood photography's power to counter racist stereotypes. He saw photography as a democratic medium that could present African Americans with dignity and humanity. The formal pose and direct gaze reflect Douglass's belief that photography could advance the cause of equality. This daguerreotype, with its sharp detail and luminous surface, exemplifies the technical excellence of mid-19th-century portrait photography while documenting one of America's most important historical figures.

departmentDescription: The Met's engagement with art from 1890 to today includes the acquisition and exhibition of works in a range of media, spanning movements in modernism to contemporary practices from across the globe.
title: The Street Pavers
description: This 1914 painting by Umberto Boccioni depicts street workers in a dynamic composition that exemplifies Italian Futurism's celebration of modern urban life and industrial progress. Boccioni was a leading figure in the Futurist movement, which sought to capture the energy, speed, and movement of the modern world. The fragmented forms and bold colors convey the rhythmic motion of labor and the transformation of the urban environment. Created during the height of Futurism, the work reflects the movement's fascination with technology, machinery, and the changing pace of contemporary life in early 20th-century Italy.

departmentDescription: The Met's engagement with art from 1890 to today includes the acquisition and exhibition of works in a range of media, spanning movements in modernism to contemporary practices from across the globe.
title: Jeanne Hébuterne
description: This 1919 portrait by Amedeo Modigliani depicts Jeanne Hébuterne, the artist's lover and muse who tragically died shortly after Modigliani himself in 1920. The painting exemplifies Modigliani's distinctive style with its elongated forms, simplified features, and warm, earthy palette. The artist's approach combines influences from African art, Italian Renaissance painting, and modern avant-garde movements. Hébuterne's melancholic expression and the painting's intimate scale reflect the close relationship between artist and subject. This work represents the culmination of Modigliani's brief but influential career in early 20th-century Paris.

departmentDescription: The Met's engagement with art from 1890 to today includes the acquisition and exhibition of works in a range of media, spanning movements in modernism to contemporary practices from across the globe.
title: Unique Forms of Continuity in Space
description: This iconic bronze sculpture by Umberto Boccioni, originally created in 1913 and cast in 1950, represents one of the masterpieces of Futurist art. The dynamic figure appears to stride forward with flowing, flame-like forms that capture the sensation of movement through space. Boccioni sought to represent not just the static human form but the interaction between body and environment, showing how motion transforms appearance. The sculpture embodies Futurist ideals about speed, dynamism, and the machine age. Its fragmented, aerodynamic surfaces suggest both human anatomy and mechanical forms, creating a powerful symbol of modernity.

departmentDescription: The Met's engagement with art from 1890 to today includes the acquisition and exhibition of works in a range of media, spanning movements in modernism to contemporary practices from across the globe.
